awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Identifying Sediment Sources and Routing of Transcontinental Drainages During Intraplate Deformation
awd_abstract_narration:
The largest rivers in the world often start in mountain ranges on one side of a continent and bring sediment to deltas on the opposite side of the continent.  The factors that allow these long-lived rivers to maintain or re-establish their courses in the face of changing geological conditions are largely unexplored.  This project will study how transcontinental rivers change with time in response to the formation of mountain ranges or basins in the rivers' pathways.  Understanding how rivers respond: whether they find a way through or around the developing mountains or basins, and how quickly they re-establish their prior courses, is critical to accurately interpreting the sedimentary record in their deltas.  In addition to providing greater insight into continental-scale rivers, this project will provide STEM training for graduate and undergraduate students and support research infrastructure and analytical facilities at a large state university and a small private university.  Further, the project will provide an opportunity for hands-on STEM training for ~30 middle school students per year under the guidance of a university professor.   

Research will focus on the "Ancestral Rocky Mountains" (ARM) and associated basins, which developed primarily in Utah, Colorado, Texas, and New Mexico 320-280 million years ago.  These basins archive changes associated with disruption and reintegration of a continental-scale river in response to ARM evolution.  This project will combine traditional and cutting-edge methods including field observations of sedimentary strata, U-Pb radiometric dating, analysis of Hf isotopes, and (U-Th)/He radiometric dating of zircons and monazite minerals in sandstones and igneous rocks to determine where sediment came from and how it changed through time.  In addition, (U-Th)/He radiometric dating on zircon minerals in igneous rocks will be used to determine when the mountain ranges developed.  These data will link changes in sediment sources to mountain and basin development through time. This will be augmented by development of new software to help determine the sources, and proportion of each source, for sediment based on radiometric dating of minerals in sandstones.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Year 4 project report

 

Accomplishments

What are the major goals of the project?

  • Develop bedrock and detrital geochronology and thermochronology datasets from across the core Ancestral Rocky Mountains (ARM) region
  • Evaluate the degree of sediment input into the core ARM region in pre-, syn-, and post-orogenic strata using numerical mixing models
  • Assess the role of intraplate deformation in rerouting or trapping sediment from transcontinental rivers
  • Support a junior faculty member and initiate collaboration between undergraduate-only institution and research-focused university

What was accomplished under these goals and objectives? 

  • Resubmission and revision of a manuscript (sediment transport and basin isolation associated with pre-, syn-, and post- ARM deformation)
  • Presentation of sedimentation transport and basin isolation research at AGU
  • Resubmission of a manuscript about source-to-sink petrochronologic characterization of detrital zircons found in the Central Colorado Trough
  • Paradox Basin provenance, stratigraphic, and basin subsidence analyses, and preparation of manuscript (material will be presented at GSA 2022).

 

Specific Objectives:

  • Moving forward, we are testing ideas of Paradox Basin connection to the Eagle Basin using provenance data and subsidence modeling.

 

Significant results:

  • Further characterized Hf isotopes and REE concentrations in zircon from the Central Colorado Trough and igneous zircons from potential sources documented.

 

Key outcomes or Other achievements:

  • We further refined and developed our new approach to sediment source mapping, and demonstrated its utility in discriminating local- versus continental scale.
  • Developed a detailed model of northern Apishapa Uplift deformation and attendant drainage reorganization and sediment source isolation in the northern Central Colorado Trough.
  • Demonstrated that Cambrian detrital zircon εHf serves as a regional proxy of provenance.

 

What opportunities for training and professional development has the project provided?

  • Collaboration with subsurface expert Don Rasmussen, and integration of his extensive experience and work in the Paradox Basin with our field and detrital zircon work in an in-depth basin analysis project.
  • Thermochronologic collaboration with Dr. Julie Fosdick (University of Connecticut).
  • Continued collaboration with Ryan Leary through shared research direction and pooling of experience. 

 

Have the results been disseminated to communities of interest? If so, please provide details:

  • One publication to be submitted
  • One publication accepted with revisions, revisions made, and now in review
  • One re-written manuscript resubmitted, and now in review
  • Presentation of Sediment Source Isolation and mapping work at AGU 2022

 

Participants/Organizations

Dr Tyson Smith (12 months; Postdoc at the University of Houston)

Were other collaborators or contacts involved? If so, please provide details. 

  • Don Rasmussen (Paradox Basin Data, LLC)
  • Julie Fosdick (University of Connecticut)

Impact

What is the impact on the development of the principal discipline(s) of the project?

  • Demonstration of sediment source isolation is some intraplate basins, and the interaction of those uplifts and depocenters with established, far-traveled sediment pathways.
  • The detrital zircon source investigation through a combination of bottom-up and top-down models is the application of existing tools in a novel approach.
  • The demonstration of a regional difference in zircon εHf from Cambrian igneous rocks provides a simple regional provenance proxy.

 

What is the impact on other disciplines?

  • Our cursory work on Cambrian age igneous rocks and their Hf isotopic ratios provides impetus to igneous geochemists to conduct a more extensive geochemical analyses focusing on the lithospheric architecture.

What is the impact on the development of human resources?

The study provided professional development of future scientists.  Supported postdoc Dr. Tyson Smith is employed at the USGS in part as a result of the training related to participation in this project.

What was the impact on teaching and educational experiences?

  • The tools and ideas developed in this project are germane to the fields of sedimentology and stratigraphy, geochronology, structural geology, and tectonics. These ideas have presented at different stages of their development in both undergraduate and graduate classes when discussing related topics and will continue to serve as examples in future classes.

What is the impact on physical resources that form infrastructure?

 

  • The tools and ideas developed in this research improve our ability to predict geologic trends (e.g., sediment composition variation in a basin) in the subsurface and surface. Therefore, this work is directly applicable to resource development (e.g., petroleum, water) and carbon sequestration (i.e., storage capacity).

 

Changes/Problems

COVID continued to delay all aspects of the project, including reporting.

Changes in approach and reasons for change

Due to delays, we are seeking a no cost extension to continue and complete the work.

Actual or Anticipated problems or delays and actions or plans to resolve them

  • We experienced delays associated with the COVID shutdown and rejection of 2 manuscripts. The former was dealt with by doing a short field season without field assistance (i.e., no field assistant), delaying presentation of material, communicating via remote channels (e.g., Zoom), and accommodating lab down time. The former was dealt with by addressing concerns of reviewers, doing extensive rewrites, and resubmitting the 2 manuscripts.

Modified by: Thomas J Lapen
